Thank you for the interesting video!  I also have a request: Would you please work on a uTube video about how water can boil at much lower than normal temperature?  I'm asking this because when I was working on a relatively high rpm centripetal water pump I observed air bubbles in the water flow output of the pump as well as a cyclic output of higher and lower water volume output from the pump.  At first I thought there must be an air leak in the water supply to the pump.  However when the pump was stopped, there was no water leaking, so I reasoned that it was unlikely that I had an air leak.  Then I had another idea, which I believe is the correct answer to the question of where the air bubbles were coming from.  The water behind the impeller blades in the pump is at a much lower pressure and is actually boiling at far less than the 120 degrees Fahrenheit that people often think water boils at.  When I told this to my boss, he looked at me like I was crazy because "everyone knows the water is no where near hot enough to boil" and I became quickly stifled.  Perhaps a well done video presentation could shed some insight into the physics of boiling water.

That statement, "There was nothing and it became everything," is a bit
misleading. My contention is that the Higgs Boson was actually
everywhere long before there was any Big bang. This would deviate the
present conception that the Higs was created in the bang and explain how
the Universe was allowed to expand faster than The speed of light as
matter was filling a void already created in which it could, shall we
say, MOVE, faster than light. Yes we can create, or believe we have
created a Higgs particle, but the fact that it is there at that time,
does not preclude that it may have been there all the while just waiting
for matter to give it purpose. The understanding that all matter was
at one time condensed into a very small point in space is fine, but why
did it just decide to, "Blow Up," so to speak. Maybe calling it the God
particle is not so far fetched after all.

The thought struck me that a gravitational wave coming from any of certain possible directions and polarized in a certain way would not be detectable by LIGO. It would be necessary to build another detector rotated 45 deg., which would about double the cost, to pick up those other possible waves. Of course the increment of data wouldn't be worth it. It's kind of like how the Arecibo radiotelescope is still scientifically useful even though it always points almost straight up.

Until now everything - and I do mean EVERYTHING - we know about the universe beyond where we've sent humans all comes from the electromagnetic spectrum. This is the first time we've been able to make an astronomical observation that doesn't directly involve photons traveling for all those light-years.

And right now what we've built is the equivalent of the very first camera. Once we start refining this technology it could lead to some remarkable and unpredictable advances, just as everything we've built on the back of that very first camera. It took 200 years before we got to the point where everyone walks around with a camera in their pockets, but I bet it will be less time than that until we all have some technology that comes from this built into our future smartphones.

I think that the estimate of the distance of the 2 black holes is wrong,. The gravitational waves occur in 4 dimensions, not just in 3. so the laser beams didn't just change their distance during the wave bypass, but also their initial time, so their frequency changed a little bit. This means that the calculated interference of the 2 beams included both changes, and showed an actually larger (or maybe smaller) distance of the event. I appreciate the importance of this discovery and thank you for helping to deliver the message of this to the world. You are making a great contribution.

As the two black holes whirl around each other, their mass creates ripples in the fabric of space, the gravity waves, which have a frequency. As the black holes approach each other (due to energy loss, carried away by the gravity wave ripples), they whirl faster and faster, increasing the frequency. At some point the frequency of the gravity waves becomes comparable to human audio frequencies. If this gravity wave signal is processed into an electrical signal and passed through an audio speaker, then we can 'hear' the gravity waves. The pitch would start out low, and as the black holes got closer to each other, the gravity wave frequency would increase, and we would hear the pitch rise, ultimately ending in a 'chirp'. Pretty cool. #010<BR> (And if you already understood all of this, be proud of your intellect. I don't need criticism for having written the explanation out. I did so for my own benefit. It helps me think it through. And, perhaps there is someone out there who enjoyed my explanation.)(However, if someone knows why my carriage returns don't appear in my comments, and would care to share how I can make them do so, I would be appreciative.)

So merging black holes produce massive and rapid oscillations in the fabric of space time which makes it possible for us to detect them. Presumably then every interacting mass will produce some sort of ripple, but these will be so weak and low frequency that detection will be much more difficult. So well done for picking them up at all, but IMO it's not a eureka moment if all we can detect are the very occasional merging black holes. Presumably more sensitive detectors would not be earth based at all and have much longer baselines?
Oh and for the end of the world conspiracy theorists, since we have just detected that super-massive black hole it means its gravity has just reached us and it is now pulling us in its direction and it will quite likely disturb the orbits of all the planets and asteroids... So the end is nigh :-)

I had seen a video explaining the main reason for uncertainty principle is that to observe somrthing we need to strike it with light then observe it to calculate its momentum and position. The act of striking any partical changes its position or momentum. Hence it cannon be calculated accurately. Minimum error is h/(2pi). Nice video, but your title is completely wrong.
The video isn't about why we care, it's all about how they detected gravitational waves.
To make a video about why we care, you would have to explain the implications of this new form of detection on physics and other fields.
Advances in other fields that come from building the detectors are not the results being able to detect gravitational waves, they are the result of people trying to prove or disprove a theory.
Has the theory been proven?
Do the waves detected correspond to those predicted?

This is a really good video, and I am a fan of science, and this is not a criticism, but how do people know what the cause of the gravitational waves was. People are saying with confidence that they came from rapidly spinning black holes 1.3 billion light years away. Surely this is just an example of something it could be. Even if there were irrefutable evidence of rotating black holes 1.3 billion light years away, who is to say that was the source? You can't even tell the direction the waves are coming from with just two detectors, as you need three for triangulation. Great video though
